channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: NATO, Finnish and Swedish Foreign Ministers to Meet
item.description: The U.S. defense secretary spoke with his Russian counterpart for the first time since the invasion. India said it would ban wheat exports as global prices rise.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mechanics repairing a tank in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv on Friday.

item.title: Sanctions Shed Light on Putin’s Private Life
item.description: As Western nations place sanctions on people close to the Russian leader, including family members, the strict secrecy surrounding his private life is being punctured.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz

item.title: As Sri Lanka Plunges Into Ruin, the Rajapaksa Family Is on the Run
item.description: Once empowered by triumphant ethnic nationalism after a brutal civil war, the Rajapaksa dynasty has been undone by what its own allies call incompetence and denial.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Skandha Gunasekara
item.media:description: From left, Mahinda Rajapaksa, Gotabaya Rajapaksa and Basil Rajapaksa in 2018. The family has dominated Sri Lanka for the better part of two decades.

item.title: North Korea Says Its Covid Outbreak Is Spreading Fast
item.description: State media reported 21 new deaths and a huge jump in suspected cases on Saturday, but it was unclear how many had been definitively linked to the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: KCNA via KNS, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, chided health officials for “incompetence” and “irresponsibility” at a meeting on Saturday, according to state media.

item.title: Israeli Police Attack Mourners at Palestinian Journalist’s Funeral
item.description: Video showed police officers in Jerusalem beating and kicking mourners next to the coffin of Shireen Abu Akleh, an Al Jazeera reporter who was killed on Wednesday, forcing one to the ground.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli security forces attacking mourners carrying the coffin of the reporter Shireen Abu Akleh on Friday.

item.title: After 200 Years of Neutrality, Sweden Weighs Joining NATO
item.description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine created new fears, and the Swedes, dragged along by Finland, are expected to apply, reluctantly, to join the alliance and its collective defense.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Sheikh Khalifa, U.A.E. Ruler, Is Dead at 73
item.description: Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan oversaw vast economic growth and built his country’s partnership with the United States in his 18 years as head of state.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan in 2013 in London.

item.title: Robredo Admits Defeat in Philippine Presidential Election
item.description: Leni Robredo urged her supporters, many of them young voters, to accept her defeat but didn’t refer to Ferdinand Marcos Jr. by name.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leni Robredo, the Philippines’ outgoing vice president, speaking to supporters on Friday.

item.title: Germany Identifies Far-Right Extremists Working in Security Services
item.description: The report reflects an effort by the authorities to come to grips with a long-running problem following several scandals involving members of the far right.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police in Dresden in January. Germany’s interior ministry released a report Friday on extremists in the country’s security services.

item.title: In South Korea, ‘Ghost Surgeries’ Lead to Cameras in Hospitals
item.description: After scandals in which doctors let unsupervised assistants operate on patients, the country is becoming one of the first to require cameras in operating rooms.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kookmin Hospital, near Seoul, voluntarily put cameras in its operating rooms in 2020. A new law will make them mandatory nationwide.

item.title: A Rabbi’s Contentious Quest for Religious Pluralism in Israel
item.description: There is more than one way to be Jewish, says Gilad Kariv, the first Reform rabbi in Israel’s Parliament. The idea poses a challenge to the country’s Orthodox establishment.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times

item.title: Life in a Ukrainian Unit: Diving for Cover, Waiting for Western Weapons
item.description: Analysts say the outcome of fighting now is riding on the accuracy, quantity and the striking power of long-range weapons. Ukraine is pleading for more.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier at a short-range artillery position in southern Ukraine monitors Russian movements in the distance.

item.title: Families Reel Outside El Salvador Prisons After Gang Violence Crackdowns
item.description: Dozens of women wait outside a detention facility for news of their loved ones after a crackdown on gang violence resulted in the imprisonment of more than 25,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives of Jonathan González López, 21, outside a prison in San Salvador after he was arrested.

item.title: Africa’s First Covid-19 Vaccine Factory Has Not Received a Single Order
item.description: Aspen Pharmacare, in South Africa, was licensed to produce the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. It was hailed as an answer to Africa’s struggle to get access to vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Walking past the site of Aspen Pharmacare’s Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine factory in Gqeberha, South Africa, last October.

item.title: An American Moment in an Australian Campaign
item.description: To some analysts, a spat over transition surgery looks like something from an overseas culture war.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison dismissed criticism of the Liberal candidate Katherine Deves as cancel cuilture.

item.title: Amid War, Ukraine Is Favored to Win Eurovision Song Contest
item.description: The exclusion of Russia from the contest has underlined the country’s estrangement from the west, including in popular culture.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kalush Orchestra, Ukraine’s representatives in the Eurovision Song Contest, performed a rousing performance of the song “Stefania” during the contest’s semifinals on Tuesday in Turn, Italy.

item.title: New Zealand’s Jacinda Ardern Tests Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: The prime minister’s rules kept transmission at bay for two years, and by the time the highly infectious Omicron variant hit, the vast majority of New Zealand’s population had been vaccinated.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand in Parliament in March, announcing the easing of some of the country’s pandemic restrictions.

item.title: Protests Triggered by Rising Food Prices Spread in Iran
item.description: “They have no hope, they have no trust in the government and they can’t tolerate the status quo any more,” one Iran expert said of the protesters in at least six provinces.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: An Iranian man walks with his shopping bags in Tehran on Friday. The Iranian government increased the price of basic food items such as cooking oil, chicken, eggs and dairy products drastically this week.

item.title: West Increases Pressure on Putin, Including Sanctions on Reputed Girlfriend
item.description: The Russian leader was challenged by the prospect of an enlarged NATO, plans to get Ukrainian grain exports past a Kremlin blockade, and sanctions on his purported mistress.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Mark Landler and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers towing a Russian armored vehicle from a bombed out bridge in the village of Rus’ka Lozova, 15 miles north of Kharkiv, on Friday.

item.title: Israeli Police Attack Mourners Before Funeral for Shireen Abu Akleh
item.description: As hundreds gathered to witness the start of Shireen Abu Akleh’s funeral procession, riot police assaulted the people carrying her coffin.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Israeli security forces attacking mourners carrying the coffin of the reporter Shireen Abu Akleh on Friday.

item.title: Treasury Warns Foreign Banks Against Helping Russia Evade Sanctions
item.description: Adewale Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, met privately with international financial institutions to make clear the consequences of sanctions evasion.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Emily Flitter
item.media:description: Adewale Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, in Washington last month. “If you provide material support to a sanctioned individual or a sanctioned entity, we can extend our sanctions regime to you and use our tools to go after you as well,” he said in an interview on Friday.

item.title: Robert C. McFarlane, Top Reagan Aide in Iran-Contra Affair, Dies at 84
item.description: As national security adviser, he pleaded guilty in an illegal scheme to aid Nicaraguan rebels in the 1980s. Guilt-ridden, he attempted suicide.
item.dc:creator: Neil A. Lewis
item.media:description: Robert C. McFarlane testifying at the Iran-contra hearings in May 1987. A former Marine, he distinguished himself in the aftermath of the scandal by his full and unequivocal acceptance of blame for his actions.

item.title: The Unlikely Ascent of New York’s Compost Champion
item.description: An ad led to Domingo Morales falling in love with compost. A windfall is helping him spread the word.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Calla Kessler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Domingo Morales, founder of Compost Power, at a public housing complex in Canarsie, Brooklyn, last month. “I have all this burning energy that never dwindles,” he said.

item.title: Ukraine Decimated Russian Forces Trying to Cross a River in the East, U.K. Says
item.description: Russian forces have been struggling to make significant progress along the eastern front.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora

item.title: Tattoos, Still Illegal in South Korea, Thrive Underground
item.description: Tattoo artists, long treated as criminals for their work, say that it is time to end the stigma against their business.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kim Do-yoon, a tattoo artist who founded a tattoo labor union, at his studio in Seoul.

item.title: Russian Court Extends Brittney Griner’s Pretrial Detention, Her Lawyer Says
item.description: Ms. Griner, one of the most decorated athletes in women’s basketball, has been held in custody in Russia since mid-February.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, a W.N.B.A. All-Star center for the Phoenix Mercury, has been detained on drug charges in Russia since Feb. 17

item.title: Did Warming Play a Role in Deadly South African Floods? Yes, a Study Says.
item.description: Climate change sharply increased the chances of catastrophic rains in the country’s east, a team of researchers has found.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: Residents of Inanda, a township north of Durban, searched rubble and debris from floods in April.

item.title: The Baby Formula Crisis
item.description: The shortage highlights four larger problems with the U.S. economy.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kaylee Greenlee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashley Aguirre, 20, feeds her one-month-old son.

item.title: Ukraine Begins Trial of Russian Soldier Accused of a War Crime
item.description: Sgt. Vadim Shysimarin is accused of shooting a 62-year-old man on a bicycle in a village in the Sumy region, about 200 miles east of Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Sgt. Vadim Shysimarin, 21, at a court hearing in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday. He is accused of shooting a civilian on a bicycle in Chupakhivka four days after the invasion began.

item.title: Russian Shipping Traffic Remains Strong as Sanctions Take Time to Bite
item.description: The traffic was robust in March and April, reflecting the time it takes for sanctions to come into effect and an enduring profit motive for trading Russian energy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tivos, a cargo ship from Russia, unloaded fertilizer last month at the Port of Santos, in São Paulo, Brazil.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Finland moves to join NATO.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lauri Heino/Lehtikuva, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of a Finnish Army brigade during exercises this year in Taipalsaari, close to the southeastern border with Russia.

item.title: North Korea Reports 6 Covid Deaths and Explosive Spread
item.description: The country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, said 187,800 people were in quarantine, and state TV showed him wearing a mask for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A TV broadcast in Seoul on Thursday showed North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, wearing a mask after the North confirmed its first Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Rand Paul Delays $40 Billion in Aid for Ukraine
item.description: Mr. Paul had sought to alter the bill to include requiring that an inspector general monitor the spending.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: People receive humanitarian aid supplies in the eastern city of Kharkiv, on Thursday.

item.title: Finland and Sweden Move Toward NATO Membership. But What About Ukraine?
item.description: Ukraine has been considered too full of corruption and too devoid of democratic institutions to make membership likely for years, if not decades, to come.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The Finnish Parliament on Thursday. The White House welcomed the announcement by Finnish leaders that their country should “apply for NATO membership without delay.”

item.title: Biden’s Summit of the Americas Threatened By Boycotts
item.description: Latin American heads of state are threatening to skip the event in Los Angeles, putting at risk the White House’s agenda in a region gripped by upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Jack Nicas
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico said he would not attend the summit if the Biden administration carries out its intent to not invite Latin America’s autocratic governments.

item.title: Finland Moves to Join NATO, Upending Putin’s Ukraine War Aims
item.description: Neutral Finland’s leaders unequivocally said they intended to seek membership in the alliance, with Sweden expected to do the same, inviting new threats from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A convoy of Ukrainian armored vehicles near the frontlines in the Donetsk region on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Is Favored to Win Eurovision as Commentator Broadcasts From Bunker
item.description: Ukraine’s entry is the song “Stefania,” from Kalush Orchestra, a band that blends traditional Ukrainian folk music with rap and hip-hop.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine’s participants in the Eurovision contest, Kalush Orchestra, are favored to win the contest with their song “Stefania.”

item.title: Why a Bullet Is the Focus of Investigations In Journalist’s Killing
item.description: The Palestinian Authority said it would not let Israeli officials examine the bullet that killed Shireen Abu Akleh. Israel said that is the only way to determine who fired it.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Raja Abdulrahim and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: The day after she was killed, Palestinian artists were already at work painting a mural of Shireen Abu Akleh in Jenin, a city in the northern West Bank.

item.title: As Southern Africa Cases Climb, Health Officials Worry About Testing Drop
item.description: New reported cases in South Africa have increased 80 percent, from the average two weeks ago, and deaths have increased 44 percent.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Testing for the coronavirus in Johannesburg last week. Cases in Southern Africa have risen significantly over the previous week, according to the World Health Organization.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The Fateful Bullet
item.description: Israeli and Palestinian authorities are divided over how to investigate the killing of the Al Jazeera journalist in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Family and friends of Shireen Abu Akleh carried her body as she arrived in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: F.B.I. Told Israel It Wanted Pegasus Hacking Tool for Investigations
item.description: A 2018 letter from the bureau to the Israeli government is the clearest documentary evidence to date that the agency weighed using the spyware for law enforcement operations.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Pegasus is produced by an Israeli firm, NSO Group, which needs to gain approval from the Israeli government before it can sell the hacking tool to a foreign government.

item.title: Boris Johnson Sidesteps Question on Donation Flagged as Russia-Linked
item.description: Britain’s prime minister said all donations are disclosed “in the normal way.” The Conservative Party gave no sign it would return the money.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson chairing a cabinet meeting in Stoke-on-Trent, Britain, on Thursday.

item.title: Biden Administration Cancels Oil Drilling Sales in Alaska and Gulf of Mexico
item.description: Republicans link the move to rising gas prices while the administration said it was a result of conflicting legal opinions and a lack of interest among bidders.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: An oil and gas platform in the Cook Inlet of Alaska in 2013.

item.title: U.K. Police Issue More Fines for Parties at Downing Street
item.description: Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, was not among those affected, his office said, though neither it, nor the police, named those who were.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: London’s Metropolitan Police have identified more than 100 cases of lawbreaking in government offices including Downing Street.

item.title: Thailand Is Easing Weed Laws and Giving Away Cannabis Plants
item.description: The Southeast Asian country will soon allow residents to grow cannabis for medicinal use. Smoking pot recreationally still carries harsh penalties.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: A greenhouse at the Rak Jang farm in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand, one of the first in the country to grow medical marijuana with official permission.

item.title: Who Is ‘Wagatha Christie’? Let Us Explain.
item.description: The feud between two television personalities has made its way to a London courtroom and the front of British tabloids. Let us explain.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Left, Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: Coleen Rooney, left, and Rebekah Vardy arrived at court in London on Thursday.

item.title: At Biden’s Summit, Other Nations Pledge Billions to Bolster Pandemic Response
item.description: The meeting was meant to reinvigorate the response as vaccination and testing lag. Many attendees said Covid fatigue had become nearly as big a danger as Covid itself.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: A woman receiving a booster shot of a coronavirus vaccine in Soweto, South Africa, earlier this month.

item.title: Interview With Gay Couple Sparks Backlash in Indonesia
item.description: The segment on a popular podcast hosted by Deddy Corbuzier enraged religious leaders, highlighting the limits of tolerance for gay people in the Muslim-majority nation.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Supporters of same-sex marriage celebrating its legalization in Taiwan in 2019.

item.title: Inflation Anger
item.description: Inflation is still high — and many Americans are upset.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Packing up groceries after shopping at Costco in Marina Del Ray, Calif.

item.title: Biden Orders Federal Flags to Fly at Half-Staff as U.S. Covid Toll Nears One Million
item.description: The president said in a formal statement that the United States must ‘remain vigilant’ against a virus that has ‘forever changed’ the country.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: American flags were lowered to half-staff on Thursday to mark the coming milestone of one million U.S. coronavirus deaths.

item.title: Biden Hosts Southeast Asian Leaders as He Tries to Return Focus to China
item.description: The leaders at the two-day summit in Washington will discuss a variety of topics, but the president plans to use it to show a united front against Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden, center, with leaders of Southeast Asian nations at the White House on Thursday. As a candidate, he promised to make China a central focus of his foreign policy.

item.title: These Dancers Escaped the War. Their Journeys Are Just Beginning.
item.description: Hundreds of ballet dancers and students fled Ukraine after Russia’s invasion. With opportunities scarce, many will have to keep moving if they want to keep dancing.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Melissa Schriek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victoria Glazunova, Kate Myklukha and Polina Loshchylina of the Dutch National Ballet.

item.title: Finland’s Leaders Urge NATO Membership ‘Without Delay’
item.description: Public opinion in Finland has shifted significantly in favor of joining the alliance in the 11 weeks since Russia invaded Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanna Marin, left, and President Sauli Niinisto in February. On thursday they announced their support for Finland to join NATO, in Helsinki on Thursday.

item.title: U.K. Donor Said to Have Funneled Russian Money to Tories
item.description: The cash was part of a fund-raising blitz that helped propel Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s party to victory in 2019. Records track $630,225 to a Russian bank account.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Forecasts for the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for humanitarian aid supplies in the city of Kharkiv, in eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: The Milky Way’s Black Hole Comes to Light
item.description: The Event Horizon Telescope has once again caught sight of the “unseeable.”
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Event Horizon Telescope Collaboration/National Science Foundation
item.media:description: The first direct image of Sagittarius A*, the black hole at the center of the Milky Way.

item.title: Kim Jong-un Orders Lockdown as North Korea Reports First Covid Cases
item.description: The country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, ordered a national lockdown after a subvariant of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus was found in the capital.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Kim Won Jin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Employees spraying disinfectant on surfaces as part of preventative measures against the coronavirus at a children’s department store in Pyongyang, North Korea.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Journalist Killed in the West Bank
item.description: Plus uncertainty about China’s wheat harvest and religious violence in India.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Shireen Abu Akleh, reporting in Jerusalem for Al Jazeera, was one of the best known Palestinian journalists.

item.title: Ukraine Launches First War Crimes Trial for Russian Soldier
item.description: A 21-year-old Russian soldier is accused of following orders to shoot an unarmed cyclist four days into Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
